stream_context.summary: Kaze spends a surprise day-off stream refining the Western-desert town level: he adds bandits, trains with VFX/SFX, coins, and finally debugs the Pokey enemy while wrestling with severe N64 memory limits.

development_findings.summary: Animated trains now have visual effects, sound effects, screen shake and can damage Mario.
development_findings.quote: They now have VFX, they have SFX, they have the camera shake and they do that to you.

development_findings.summary: Bandit NPCs steal goods from a hat shop and tumbleweed shop; this storytelling trick avoids modelling extra props, saving RAM.
development_findings.quote: This is a trick we do so we don't actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.

development_findings.summary: The level hit the 64 MB ceiling (40 k triangles, ROM 62.7 MB).  Kaze cut the Yoshi Ranch area and began trimming collision meshes, unused banks, and considering per-area data loads.
development_findings.quote: We are out of memory ... I'm fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch. I think that was unnecessary fluff anyway.

development_findings.summary: Placeholder songs are a major memory drain; final music will free space once temporary lumps are removed.
development_findings.quote: There's like 15 minutes of code slumps in here that aren't actually part of the game.

development_findings.summary: Vanilla SM64 Pokey performs 37 floor raycasts per frame; Kaze’s engine optimised them away, breaking the enemy.  Restoring per-frame floor checks and billboard scaling fixed it.
development_findings.quote: For some reason a Pokey needs 6 Raycasts—actually 37 Raycasts every tick.

development_findings.summary: Billboard matrix in his engine ignores scale, so Pokey head had to be up-scaled 3.33× and rotated 180° to render correctly.
development_findings.quote: Our billboard matrix cannot take a scale.

development_findings.summary: Spawn/despawn distances for Pokey increased to 5 000/6 000 units now that performance issues are resolved.
Using SM64 decomp rather than ROM Manager complicates per-area memory because of C linker hurdles.
development_findings.quote: In D-Comp, it's so hard to just have data per area ... there’s a lot of stupid C things you need to do.

context_findings.summary: PayPal froze Kaze’s account for three months, blocking music-request donations mid-stream.
context_findings.quote: They asked me to verify my identity three months ago ... and now they just closed my account basically.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a week off from his paid job at Gears for Breakfast and spends it streaming ROM-hack work.
context_findings.quote: I’m off work for this week ... it's a bonus stream.

context_findings.summary: He benches 315 lbs but feels over-trained; mentions needing more rest days.
context_findings.quote: My body feels so fucked up today ... I increased the weight so much, I need to take more rest days.

context_findings.summary: Expresses disdain for boss fights, 2D platformers, and idioms; values concise, precise language.
context_findings.quote: I value language that is concise and precise, so if you just add on things, they tend to make it worse for me.

biobak.summary: Discussed metallic vs. matte teeth on Chain Chomp and other texture tweaks.
Will create a Pokey model for Bowser’s amusement-park level and a tumbleweed store scene.
biobak.quote: I gotta ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here ... You’re right, I will just reuse that [Pokey] one.

badub.summary: Soundtrack currently 70 % SM64 sound-font but used creatively to feel fresh.
badub.quote: It’s freaking amazing how different from the default Mario 64 sound ... 70 % of the instruments, but they’re used in really creative ways.

zeina.summary: Tasked with tumbleweed-store assets and Pokey/Dry Bones animations; present in chat despite panic episode.
zeina.quote: Let me ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here.

key_stories.title: Pokey Resurrection
key_stories.summary: Kaze tried to drop the vanilla Pokey into the new engine; it rendered invisibly and floated. He discovered his optimisation removed essential per-frame floor raycasts and billboard scaling.
key_stories.challenge: Pokey segments spawned but instantly vanished or flew overhead.
key_stories.process: Stubbed out functions, printed debug info, compared with vanilla, reinstated floor checks, fixed billboard scale and rotation.
key_stories.outcome: Pokey now works, with correct shadow, size and spawn range.
key_stories.key_quote: We finally fixed it. Took forever because some random Mario 64 functions broke when I optimised my stuff.

key_stories.title: RAM Crisis in the Desert Level
key_stories.summary: The Western town exceeded N64 memory.  Crashes forced immediate cuts and optimisation.
key_stories.challenge: Level at 62.7 MB crashed when loading OpenGL layout.
key_stories.process: Removed Yoshi Ranch, merged collision meshes, considered deleting effect/command banks, studied memory overlay to locate free blocks.
key_stories.outcome: Level now loads; per-area loading still on the table.
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly, I'm fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch. I think that was unnecessary fluff anyway.

key_stories.title: Donation Blackout
key_stories.summary: Music-request donations failed live on stream.
key_stories.challenge: Streamlabs sent tips to an old, now-blocked PayPal.
key_stories.process: Checked Streamlabs, PayPal, email; realised account verification stall.
key_stories.outcome: No fix yet; Kaze may need new payment pipeline.
key_stories.key_quote: It just goes to the wrong email address ... I don't know what to do about this right now.
